Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Damage Compliant Inelastic Design Parameters for Performance-Based-Seismic-Design of Slender RC Columns

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop and calibrate inelastic modeling parameters that better correlate damage to performance of slender reinforced concrete (RC) bridge columns. The specific modeling parameter to be investigated is the so-called plastic hinge length, which facilitates design and analysis tasks related to inelastic behavior. The approach will employ a mechanics-based methodology and progress from simple computational tools to high-fidelity modeling of the inelastic response of RC columns. Linking of these computational tools to a rigorous experimental program with accurate localized measurements will provide the necessary data to validate and calibrate the new mechanics-based models. The research will result in newly calibrated/validated plastic hinge length models with improved correlation and/or compliance with local damage that develop in RC bridge columns during seismic loads. Deliverables include new models for defining plastic hinge length that balance the design convenience and the analytical rigor of mechanics, while providing accuracy in their ability to relate to damage.


Current state of the art in seismic design is moving towards prescribing localized strain levels that correlate to a well-defined damage level. If successful, the research will provide valuable numerical tools for practitioners and researchers to use in the assessment/design of RC columns within this emerging design philosophy. The research will create a unifying framework for inelastic modeling in performance based design, which will be applicable to a range of column sizes in bridge and building structures. Research results will be archived in open-access repositories for utilization by others. Educational resources for undergraduate and graduate students such as a virtual structural testing laboratory will be created to facilitate their learning. Outreach activities are planned for K-12 students and freshmen engineering students. The PIs will leverage the project with REU supplementary funding for summer research fellowships exclusively targeted at underrepresented students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Successful implementation of modern seismic design philosophies requires linking levels of acceptable damage, to a given seismic risk, by using reliable inelastic design parameters that correlate well to the defined damage levels. The spread of plasticity in reinforced concrete (RC) columns is an important response feature and its simplification into the notion of a “plastic hinge” is a common design/analysis inelastic parameter. Yet, careful evaluation of recent and commonly used models shows wide scatter against experimental data and poor compliance with the intended damage level, particularly when applied to limit states other than ultimate. The problem worsens when considering slender columns, or those with aspect ratios of length (L) over depth (D) of 8 or greater. The project’s research hypothesis was that available inelastic design parameter, i.e., plastic hinge, models for RC columns, particularly for slender ones, were poor predictors of intermediate damage limit states due to limited calibration with local damage measures and the near lack of data for slender columns.

Current plastic hinge models, as incorporated in lumped plasticity finite elements, as well as higher fidelity approaches, namely distributed plasticity finite elements were evaluated for their ability to capture multiple damage levels. By analyzing data from the PEER Structural Performance Database it was found that current plastic hinge models do not offer the accuracy needed for predicting intermediate limit states. Further, no significant evidence was found to consider the lumped plasticity or the distributed plasticity nonlinear beam-element formulations as a more appropriate analysis tool for prediction of inelastic behavior.

Four half-scale RC circular bridge columns with L/D ratios of 10 and 12 were tested to study the effects of slenderness, axial load and reinforcement ratio, as well as to create previously unavailable data for this kinds of columns. Three pseudo-static tests and one pseudo-dynamic test were conducted. It was found that the height of the plastic region can be underestimated by up to 25 % for slender columns if the effect of P-δ (member slenderness) is ignored. The length of the plastic hinge region, as defined by current seismic design guidelines from ACI and AASHTO for ultimate response, was exceeded shortly after inelastic actions started. For the tested columns the experimental plastic region exceeded the design code limits for special detailing at displacement ductility levels of about 1.5. However, AASHTO’s criteria can be improved with a refined estimate of the ideal yield moment and consideration of member deformations (P-δ effects) in extracting the moment profiles. It was found that current stability limits seem to be too conservative when applied to columns with high aspect ratios.

High-fidelity three-dimensional (3D) finite element (FE) modeling was used to establishing a connection between inelastic parameters and intermediate damage limit states (IDLS), which damage conditions in a structural element and that define key levels of performance and repair requirements. Results showed that the 3D FE simulations were efficient in predicting IDLS in a consistent manner with experimental observations. However, the accuracy of FE simulations varies when predicting structural responses at different local and global damage levels. Of significance to slender columns, it was found that the onset of spalling in terms of drift increased from 1.3% to 3.0% as the columns’ aspect ratio increased from 6 to 12.
